description: Only Alabama residents and Alabama-based companies can request public records under the Open Records Act
notes: Restricts access to residents only, excluding out-of-state requesters

description: Executive agencies have 15 business days for standard requests, 45-180 business days for time-intensive requests
notes: Unusually long timeframes compared to most states

description: Agency may not charge a fee for the first two person-hours spent searching for or copying public records in a calendar month
notes: Unique provision protecting requesters from initial search costs

description: Agency must find that need for confidentiality outweighs public interest in disclosure, considering 8 specific factors
notes: Structured analysis required for withholding decisions

description: Most agencies must provide administrative appeal process before court action
notes: Requires exhausting administrative remedies in many cases

description: Requesters seeking records for commercial purpose must provide statement; custodian can seek Governor's executive order to prohibit
notes: Governor has authority to block commercial use requests via executive order

description: Must acknowledge written request within 5 business days (since 2023)
notes: Recent legislative addition improving response transparency

description: Unlawful refusal to allow examination is class 2 misdemeanor; failure to comply with response requirements is class 2 misdemeanor
Must be Arkansas citizen to request records
notes: Restricts access to state residents only

description: Request may be made in person, by telephone, by mail, by facsimile transmission, by electronic mail, or by other electronic means
notes: Explicitly permits telephone requests in statute

category: Attorney General Opinion for Personnel Records
description: For personnel/evaluation records, requester or subject may seek Attorney General opinion within 3 working days
notes: Special expedited AG review process for personnel matters

description: Cannot charge search fees (unlike federal FOIA)
10 days to determine if records exist and will be disclosed; additional 14 days in unusual circumstances (no further extensions)
notes: Strict limit on extensions prevents indefinite delays

description: May charge research and retrieval fee only if more than one hour of staff time necessary; no fee for first hour
notes: Protects requesters from initial hour of search costs

description: Before judicial review, person may file written request for reconsideration with custodian; 14-day waiting period before court
Independent 9-member commission handles appeals, issues binding orders, imposes civil penalties up to $1,000
notes: Strong independent oversight body with enforcement powers

description: State agencies: max $0.25/page; other public agencies: max $0.50/page; Judicial Dept: $0.50 first 20 pages, $0.25 thereafter
notes: Different fee caps for different agency types

description: Agencies must respond within 4 business days
All state agencies and public bodies must develop web portals for receiving FOIA requests using AG standard form
First 20 pages of standard black and white material provided free of charge
notes: Substantial free access before fees apply

description: Citizens may petition AG for determination of whether violation occurred; AG must respond within 30 days
Can request by phone, in writing, or in person; no specific form required
notes: Most flexible request format - oral requests explicitly permitted

description: No requirement to state purpose or provide identification
No specific response timeframes; must make 'good faith effort' within 'reasonable period'
Article I, Section 24 of Florida Constitution establishes right of access to public records
No charge for first quarter hour (15 minutes) of research/retrieval time
Records not in active use must be provided immediately; 3 business day maximum if in active use/storage
notes: Fastest response requirement when records readily available

description: If estimated cost exceeds $25, agency may request requester confirm willingness to pay; if over $500, may require 50% deposit
Independent oversight agency administers UIPA, handles appeals, issues binding determinations
Requesters can typically remain anonymous
Statute lists 16 categories of records that must be disclosed
notes: Affirmative disclosure requirements beyond typical access

description: Idaho residents: 3-10 working days; Non-residents: up to 35 days
notes: Dramatic difference in response times based on residency

description: May waive fees if request 'contributes significantly to public understanding of government operations or activities'
PAC provides binding determinations on FOIA requests (with limited exceptions)
notes: Strong administrative enforcement through binding decisions

description: First 50 pages of black and white copies provided free
Commercial requests: 21 working days to respond (vs. 5 days for standard requests)
$2,500-$5,000 civil penalties for willful and intentional violations
PAC issues advisory opinions (not binding) but provides guidance
notes: Advisory rather than binding administrative review

description: Initial request need not be made in person or in writing; can be oral
No fixed deadline; must provide within 'reasonable time' based on agency size, request size, complexity
notes: Flexible standard rather than fixed days

description: Independent board enforces sunshine laws, handles complaints, issues formal opinions
Exemptions are discretionary, not mandatory - narrowly construed in favor of disclosure
notes: Agency choice to withhold even when exemption applies

description: Cannot charge for first hour of research time
Agencies must make reasonable efforts to contact requesters when staff time exceeds 5 hours or cost exceeds $200
Statute contains 55 specific exemptions (expanded from original fewer)
Liberal construction standard specifically for fiscal records, audits, and public fund documents
notes: Special disclosure presumption for financial records

description: Kentucky 'residents' include individuals, domestic businesses, registered out-of-state businesses, workers in KY, property owners, authorized agents, and news organizations
notes: Broad definition of 'resident' for access purposes

description: Strong AG enforcement role; issues binding decisions unless appealed; decisions have precedential value and are online
notes: Robust administrative review with precedential decisions

description: Strict 30-day deadline to appeal AG decision; if not appealed, AG decision 'has force and effect of law'
notes: Unusually strict and binding administrative decision process

description: Non-commercial users pay only reproduction costs; no search time charges
notes: Protection from search costs for public interest requests

description: Louisiana Constitution Article XII, Section 3 provides constitutional protection beyond statutory rights
$100 per day civil penalty against custodian for arbitrary refusal to respond
Direct court access after 5-day response period; no bureaucratic delays
Cases heard by preference and in summary manner; appellate courts place on preferential docket
First 2 hours of staff time are free
Advisory committee assists with FOAA implementation
Requires training for public officials on FOAA requirements
Ombudsman mediates disputes (non-binding) before formal complaints
Formal compliance board reviews complaints after ombudsman consultation
Must respond within 30 days; 10 working days if longer needed
Each agency and municipality must designate Records Access Officer to coordinate responses
Primary appeal authority in Office of Secretary of Commonwealth
RAO must respond within 10 business days (excluding weekends, holidays, unexpected closures)
5 business days to respond; may extend additional 10 days with written notice (only one extension)
Must provide detailed fee estimate if costs expected to exceed $50
Punitive damages available for bad faith denials
General requests: 'as soon as reasonably possible'; Data subject requests: 10 business days maximum
notes: Different standards for different request types

description: Each agency must designate Responsible Authority to comply with data practices
Records classified as: Public, Nonpublic, Protected Nonpublic, or Confidential
Current statute expires July 1, 2028 - new legislation may be required
If no written procedures: provide access within 1 working day after written request
notes: Rapid default timeline when no procedures exist

description: Public bodies encouraged to adopt own reasonable written procedures for cost, time, place, method
Must respond 'as soon as possible' but no later than end of third business day
Cannot charge for first hour of research time
Maximum 10 cents per page for standard copies
Montana Constitution Article II, Section 9 provides constitutional right to examine documents and observe deliberations
Executive branch has specific 5-day acknowledgment and response requirements; non-executive responds 'in timely manner'
notes: Different standards for different government branches

category: Privacy Must Clearly Exceed Disclosure Merit
description: Individual privacy must 'clearly exceed the merits of public disclosure' to justify withholding
Within 4 business days must: provide records, deny with citations, or explain delay with earliest date
Liberal construction required for fiscal records, audits, vouchers, invoices, and public fund documents
Denial must include description of withheld record contents and specific statutory citations
Within 5 business days must: allow access, notify location, estimate if within 30 days, or deny with citation
Failure to act within 5 business days deemed a denial
Statutes making records confidential must be strictly and narrowly construed
Dedicated ombudsman handles FOIA complaints and provides guidance
Court may impose civil penalties up to $2,000 for violations
Court may order mandatory training for officials who violate law
24-hour notice required for regular public meetings
Requestors must certify whether request connected to legal proceeding (2024 amendment)
notes: New requirement to prevent discovery bypass

description: Email/correspondence requests must include discrete time period, specific subject matter, and employee names/titles (2024)
Agencies must keep records on publicly available website 'to extent feasible' with search functionality (2024)
Prevailing requestor gets attorney fees only if agency unreasonably denied, acted in bad faith, or knowingly violated OPRA (2024)
notes: Higher burden for fee recovery after 2024

description: First 10 pages provided at no charge
GRC provides mediation and formal investigation with appealable decisions
Maximum 15 calendar days to respond; 3 business days triggers written explanation requirement
notes: Clear maximum with early notification trigger

description: Search fees are NOT permitted in New Mexico
AG has statutory authority to enforce IPRA; can file lawsuits if informal resolution fails
ALL medical records exempt (broader than most states)
5 business days to grant/deny/acknowledge; up to 20 additional days from acknowledgment (total 25)
Provides guidance and handles certain appeals for FOIL matters
Agencies with email capability must accept and respond to FOIL requests electronically
Records furnished 'as promptly as possible' - no specific deadline in statute
Fees cannot exceed actual cost of reproduction
Willful destruction of public records is Class 1 misdemeanor
North Dakota Constitution Article XI, Section 6 (1977) provides constitutional right to access
citation: North Dakota Constitution Article XI, Section 6

description: Records available during 'reasonable office hours' - no statutory response deadline
May not ask for motive, reason for requesting, or identity of requestor
May charge up to $25/hour for locating records only if exceeding one hour
Must acknowledge receipt within 1 business day
All public offices must adopt written public records policies
All elected officials or designees must attend training on public records requirements
Statutory damages up to $1,000 ($100/day) for violations
Offices must help clarify ambiguous requests and explain record organization
Must provide 'prompt, reasonable access' during regular business hours - no specific deadline

category: No Search Fees for Public Interest
description: No search fee when release is in public interest, including news media, scholars, authors, taxpayers
$100 damages per purposeful violation plus court costs and attorney fees
Public bodies must post regular business hours in prominent public view
Acknowledge within 5 business days; respond within 15 business days unless justified extension
Request must be in writing with name, address, and description of records
If fee will exceed $25, must provide written estimate and await confirmation
May petition DA or AG to review denial; they can order production
OOR handles appeals with appeals officers issuing determinations within 30 days
Each agency must designate open-records officer responsible for compliance
5 business days to respond; 30 days to fulfill unless scope requires extension
Failure to respond within 5 business days deems request denied
Must appeal to OOR within 15 business days of denial or deemed denial
10 business days to respond; up to additional 20 days if voluminous/complex
No fee for first hour of search/retrieval time
Search fees cannot exceed $15/hour based on lowest paid capable employee
Court may impose civil fine up to $1,000 for arbitrary or capricious denial
May file complaint with AG who investigates and may institute court proceedings
Rhode Island was 49th state to enact FOIA law (1979)
15 calendar days to respond; 30 days to furnish (35 for records over 24 months old)
May require deposit up to 25% of estimated cost if reproduction exceeds $25
$500 civil fine for arbitrary and capricious violations
Must be construed liberally in favor of openness
Action must be commenced within one year after person knew or should have known of violation
Prior to 2009, records presumed confidential; SB 147 reversed to presumption of public access
Better Government Association ranked South Dakota 50th for transparency in 2008
Administrative appeals through hearing examiners with binding decisions
May charge fees after first hour of staff time
Written requests must receive response within 10 business days
Only citizens of Tennessee have right to inspect and receive public records
Must respond within 7 business days: provide records, deny, or furnish completed response form with timeline
Each entity must designate PRRC responsible for prompt and efficient processing
Provides guidance, develops standard forms, assists with disputes
As of 2018, 563 exemptions exist throughout Tennessee Code
Agencies must request AG opinion within 10 business days to withhold; AG decides within 45 working days
Must respond 'promptly' - reasonable time to produce information
Must notify third parties if proprietary information involved
Independent ombudsman mediates disputes, provides guidance (non-binding)
Committee schedules hearings within 5 days, issues binding orders
Records classified as Public, Private, Controlled, or Protected
Statewide online portal for submitting requests, tracking status
5 business days for expedited requests that benefit public
First 10 single-sided copies free; searches 15 minutes or less free
Record must be produced or certified exempt within 3 business days
Staff time charges only if request exceeds 30 minutes
Statute declares 'government is the servant of the people and not the master of them'
State agencies: 9 AM-12 PM and 1 PM-4 PM except weekends/holidays
No administrative appeal process - direct court review only
Council provides guidance, training, advisory opinions, maintains FOIA officer directory
5 working days to respond; may extend 7 additional days (total 12 maximum)
Mandamus petition heard within 7 days of filing
PROs and governing body members must complete PRA training within 90 days; refresher every 4 years
Each agency must designate PRO as primary contact
More than 500 total exemptions throughout Washington statutes
Daily penalty of $5-$100 per day for each day of violation
AG maintains Model Rules (WAC 44-14) providing detailed guidance
Public body may NOT charge search or retrieval fee
Secretary of State maintains publicly accessible online database of all FOIA requests since 2016
Each agency must report nature of request, response, timeframe, and fees to Secretary of State
Respond within 5 business days
'As soon as practicable and without delay' - generally 10 business days for simple requests
Cannot charge fee for providing access for inspection
May charge for locating records only if cost exceeds $50; must provide written estimate
Minimum $100 damages if court finds arbitrary and capricious denial
Statute construed with presumption of complete public access; denial contrary to public interest except in exceptional cases
Governor designates ombudsman to assist public with access
Acknowledge within 7 business days; produce within 30 calendar days
Each entity must designate public records person responsible for responding
Training required for designated records person and other employees
20 business days to respond (excluding Saturdays, Sundays, legal holidays)
May extend up to 10 additional working days in unusual circumstances
Nine specific exemptions (b)(1) through (b)(9)
Each agency must designate Chief FOIA Officer
Agencies must maintain electronic FOIA request portal
Search fees waived if agency fails to meet time limits
Different fee structures for commercial, media, educational, and other requesters
